com.guidewire.ab.webservices.api

Interface IDataObjectAPI

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.rmi.Remote
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    IDataObjectAPISoapBindingStub
    Deprecated. 
    Write your own Gosu class and publish it as a web service.

    public interface IDataObjectAPI
extends java.rmi.Remote
    Deprecated interface. There is no replacement. Instead, you should write your own Gosu class and publish it as a web service by marking it with the @RpcWebService annotation.

    Methods in this class use XPath. The notation draws heavily from the new "Service Data Object" spec from BEA and IBM. See their Service Data Ojbects specification. Please note that certain characters need to be escaped in XPath notation. Specifically: ' goes to '
    " goes to &qout;
    < goes to <
    > goes to >
    & goes to &

    Version:
    Jan 16, 2004 4:15:21 PM
    Author:
    mshaw

    • Method Detail

      • find

        GWObject[] find(java.lang.String entityType,
              java.lang.String alias,
              java.lang.String whereClause,
              ObjectFilter filter)
                throws java.rmi.RemoteException,
                       ServerStateException,
                       PermissionException,
                       SOAPException,
                       BadIdentifierException
        Deprecated. 

        Find a set of objects of the same type using the Gosu finder notation. See the Gosu Reference Guide for details on how to build a where clause. The result set's size is capped by default at 100 objects. To override the default, set the GW_MAX_OBJECT_RETRIEVAL_PROPERTY property in the SOAP header using SOAPOutboundHandler.

        This method is deprecated. Returning all the matching object data without first knowing the size of the matching set can be expensive. Instead, use findIds to find the matching set of ids and getObjectById or getPathValues to load the associated entity data.

        Parameters:
        entityType - The type of entity to find. Type is case-insensitive, e.g. "Claim" and "claim" are both valid entity types.
        alias - Used in the the where clause to refer to the root type being returned, for example, "c".
        whereClause - Criteria to apply when finding objects. See the Gosu Reference Guide for details on how to build a where clause.
        filter - Object filter to apply to the root object. See ObjectFilter for details on how the filter is applied to an object graph. A null filter will return the entire object graph, for example, Claim and its related objects such as Policy and Contacts. This can have negative performance implications and even cause OutOfMemoryErrors if the object graph returned is too large. To avoid these types of problems, a filter that limits the returned data to just the desired fields should be used if possible.
        Returns:
        Array of objects that match the where clause criteria
        Throws:
        ServerStateException - Thrown when a request is made at a time the server is in a state that disallows the request.
        PermissionException - Thrown when the authenticated SOAP user does not have permission to perform the requested operation
        SOAPException
        BadIdentifierException - If the entity type is invalid
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if a communication error occurs

      • findIds

        FindIdsResult findIds(java.lang.String entityType,
                    java.lang.String alias,
                    java.lang.String whereClause)
                      throws java.rmi.RemoteException,
                             ServerStateException,
                             PermissionException,
                             SOAPException,
                             BadIdentifierException
        Deprecated. 

        Find a set of public Ids of the same type using the Gosu finder notation. See the Gosu Reference Guide for details on how to build a where clause. The size of the result set is capped by default at 100 objects. To override this default set the GW_MAX_OBJECT_RETRIEVAL_PROPERTY property in the soap header using SOAPOutboundHandler.

        Example

        In the following example, a Gosu finder expression is translated into a call to findIds(): The following Gosu expression: 

         findIds(Claim with c in Claim where c.LossType == "AUTO" and
 c.AccidentType != "46")

        Becomes the following with IDataObjectAPI call:

         findIds("Claim", "c", "c.LossType == \"AUTO\" and c.AccidentType
 != \"46\"")

        Use getObjectById to load the associated object data.


        Parameters:
        entityType - The type of entity to find. Type is case-insensitive, as a result "Claim" and "claim" are both valid entity types.
        alias - Used in the where clause to refer to the root type being returned, for example "c".
        whereClause - Criteria to apply when finding objects. See the Gosu Reference Guide for details on how to build a where clause.
        Returns:
        A set of public Ids
        Throws:
        ServerStateException - Thrown when a request is made at a time the server is in a state that disallows the request.
        PermissionException - Thrown when the authenticated SOAP user does not have permission to perform the requested operation
        SOAPException
        BadIdentifierException - If the entity type is invalid
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if a communication error occurs

      • getNextSequenceNumber

        long getNextSequenceNumber(java.lang.String sequenceKey,
                         long minValue)
                           throws java.rmi.RemoteException,
                                  ServerStateException,
                                  PermissionException,
                                  SOAPException,
                                  BadIdentifierException
        Deprecated. 

        Get the next sequence number for a sequence key.

        If this is a new sequence key a new sequence is created with initial value minValue. If the sequence exists then the next number in the sequence is returned. The sequence numbers are unique across a cluster.


        Parameters:
        sequenceKey - The sequenceKey on which a sequence number will be generated for.
        minValue - if the sequenceKey is new, it will be created and initialized with minValue.
        Returns:
        A unique sequence number for this sequence key.
        Throws:
        ServerStateException - Thrown when a request is made at a time the server is in a state that disallows the request.
        PermissionException - Thrown when the authenticated SOAP user does not have permission to perform the requested operation
        SOAPException
        BadIdentifierException - If the entity type is invalid
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if a communication error occurs

      • getObjectById

        GWObject getObjectById(java.lang.String entityType,
                     java.lang.String publicId,
                     ObjectFilter filter)
                       throws java.rmi.RemoteException,
                              ServerStateException,
                              PermissionException,
                              SOAPException,
                              BadIdentifierException
        Deprecated. 

        Get an object graph by the public Id of the root object.


        Parameters:
        entityType - The type of root entity. Type is case-insensitive, e.g. "Claim" and "claim" are both valid entity types.
        publicId - The publicId of the root object to return.
        filter - Object filter to apply to the root object. See ObjectFilter for details on how the filter is applied to an object graph. A NULL filter will return the entire object graph, e.g. Claim and its related objects such as Policy and Contacts. This can have negative performance implications and even cause OutOfMemoryErrors if the object graph returned is too large. To avoid these types of problems, a filter that limits the returned data to just the desired fields should be used if possible.
        Returns:
        Root object of the object graph, NULL if an entity with that publicId does not exist.
        Throws:
        ServerStateException - Thrown when a request is made at a time the server is in a state that disallows the request.
        PermissionException - Thrown when the authenticated SOAP user does not have permission to perform the requested operation
        SOAPException
        BadIdentifierException - If the entity type is invalid
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if a communication error occurs

      • getPathValues

        java.lang.String[][] getPathValues(java.lang.String entityType,
                                 java.lang.String publicId,
                                 java.lang.String[] paths)
                                   throws java.rmi.RemoteException,
                                          ServerStateException,
                                          PermissionException,
                                          SOAPException,
                                          BadIdentifierException
        Deprecated. 

        Returns properties accessed from a root entity. Specify the paths as strings. A single path may return multiple values if the path traverses an array. Multiple paths return a two-dimensional array of values, an array for each path specified.

        A path can traverse any entity property but only a writeable property's value can be set. This is the same set of properties that is accessible from Gosu. See the Gosu API Reference in Studio for a list of accessible properties. The set of available properties is a super-set of the "exportable" properties that exist on SOAP entities.

        The path leaf must reference a "simple" property (not an entity or array) but the path can traverse through entities and arrays.

        Specify the path in XPath notation. The notation draws heavily from the new "Service Data Object" spec from BEA and IBM. See their Service Data Ojbects specification.

        NOTE: Array elements are indexed starting at 1 not 0.

        Example

        Get the names of all the users in a group. 

        
 String[] path = new String[1]
 path[0] = "users/user/credential/username"
 api.getPathValues("group", "315", path)

        Get the public Ids of all the users in a group with a LoadFactor > 50 

        
 String[] path = new String[1]
 path[0] = "users[LoadFactor >= 50]/user/publicId"
 api.getPathValues("group", "315", path)

        Parameters:
        entityType - The type of root entity. The type is case-insensitive, e.g. "Claim" and "claim", are both valid types.
        publicId - The ID of the root object from which all paths originate.
        paths - Paths of the properties to return.
        Returns:
        A two-dimensional array of string values. Each path specified has a corresponding string array in the results. The results return in the same order as the paths were specified. If a path returns no values, then its array is empty.
        Throws:
        ServerStateException - Thrown when a request is made at a time the server is in a state that disallows the request.
        PermissionException - Thrown when the authenticated SOAP user does not have permission to perform the requested operation
        SOAPException
        BadIdentifierException - If the entity type is invalid
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if a communication error occurs

      • setPathValues

        SetPathValuesResult setPathValues(java.lang.String entityType,
                                java.lang.String publicId,
                                InsertPathValue[] add,
                                PathValue[] update,
                                java.lang.String[] remove)
                                  throws java.rmi.RemoteException,
                                         ServerStateException,
                                         PermissionException,
                                         SOAPException,
                                         BadIdentifierException
        Deprecated. 

        Add, update, and remove values on entities relative to a root entity. All changes are made in the same transaction. If one change fails none of the changes are applied.

        A path can traverse any entity property but only a writeable property's value can be set. An entity's writeable properties are the same set of properties accessible from Gosu. See the API Help in Studio for a list of accessible properties. The set of accessible properties is a super-set of the "exportable" properties available to SOAP entities.

        A path's leaf must reference a "simple" property (not an entity or array) but the path can traverse through entities and arrays.

        Specify the path in XPath notation. The notation draws heavily from the "Service Data Object" specification put out by BEA and IBM.

        NOTE: Array elements are indexed starting at 1 not 0.

        Add Example

        This example associates an existing user to a group by adding a new GroupUser entity linking the two. The value of newGroupUser/user on the newGroupUser is in the form entityType:publicId, where user is the entityType and 74 is the user's publicId. 

        
 InsertPathValue[] add = new InsertPathValue[1]
 add[0] = new InsertPathValue()
 add[0].setPath("users")
 add[0].setRefId("newGroupUser")
 PathValue[] update = new PathValue[2]
 update[0] = new PathValue()
 update[0].setPath("newGroupUser/user")
 update[0].setValue("user:74")
 update[1] = new PathValue()
 update[1].setPath("newGroupUser/loadfactor")
 update[1].setValue("80")
 String remove = new String[0]
 api.setPathValues("group", "315", add, update, remove)

        Remove Example

        Disassociate a user from a group by removing the GroupUser entity that links them. 74 is publicId of the user being removed from the group. 

        
 InsertPathValue[] add = new InsertPathValue[0]
 PathValue[] update = new PathValue[0]
 String[] remove = new String[1]
 remove[0] = "users[user/publicId='74']"
 api.setPathValues("group", "315", add, update, remove)

        Parameters:
        entityType - The type of root entity. The type is case-insensitive, for example, Claim and claim are both valid types. If only "rootless" entities are being added then entityType can be null.
        publicId - The ID of the root object from which all the paths start. If only "rootless" entities are being added then entityType can be null.
        add - Path values of entities to add. The path leaf can be null or refer to an array or a foreign key link. If the path is null then a new "rootless" entity is inserted. The refId is used to reference the new entity when setting properties using update paths.
        update - Path values of properties to set. If setting properties on a newly inserted entity then start the path with the refId of the new entity.
        remove - Paths that point to entities to remove. The leaf of the path must refer to a specific array element or a foreign key link. An empty path ("") will remove the root entity.
        Returns:
        SetPathValuesResult with the public Ids of any newly inserted entities.
        Throws:
        ServerStateException - Thrown when a request is made at a time the server is in a state that disallows the request.
        PermissionException - Thrown when the authenticated SOAP user does not have permission to perform the requested operation
        SOAPException
        BadIdentifierException - If the entity type is invalid
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if a communication error occurs

      • setPathValues

        void setPathValues(java.lang.String entityType,
                 java.lang.String publicId,
                 PathValue[] pathValues)
                   throws java.rmi.RemoteException,
                          ServerStateException,
                          PermissionException,
                          SOAPException,
                          BadIdentifierException
        Deprecated. 

        Update values on entities relative to a root entity. All changes will be made in the same transaction. If one change fails none of the changes will be applied.

        A path can traverse any entity property but only a writeable property's value can be set. This is the same set of properties that is accessible from Gosu. This Gosu API Reference contains a list of accessible properties. The set of available properties is a super-set of the "exportable" properties that exist on SOAP entities.

        The leaf of a path must reference a "simple" property (not an entity or array) but the path can traverse through entities and arrays.

        Specify the path in XPath notation. The notation draws heavily from the "Service Data Object" specification put out by BEA and IBM.

        NOTE: Array elements are indexed starting at 1 not 0.

        Example

        Change the load factor of a group's parent. 

        
 PathValue[] update = new PathValue[1]
 update[0].setPath("parent/group/loadfactor")
 update[0].setValue("50")
 api.setPathValues("group", "315", update)

        Parameters:
        entityType - The type of root entity. The type is case-insensitive, e.g. "Claim" and "claim", are both valid types.
        publicId - The ID of the root object from which all paths will start
        pathValues - Array of path values to set. Each path value has a path, starting from the root, and a value, which is the new value to set on the field which is at the "leaf" of the path.
        Throws:
        ServerStateException - Thrown when a request is made at a time the server is in a state that disallows the request.
        PermissionException - Thrown when the authenticated SOAP user does not have permission to perform the requested operation
        SOAPException
        BadIdentifierException - If the entity type is invalid
        java.rmi.RemoteException - if a communication error occurs
